greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Omit the 1s from Rowland's sequence f(n) - f(n-1) = gcd(n,f(n-1)), where f(1) = 7.
comment: Rowland proves that each term is prime. He says it is likely that all odd primes occur.
In the first 5000 terms, there are 965 unique primes and 397 is the least odd prime that does not appear. - _T. D. Noe_, Mar 01 2008
In the first 10000 terms, the least odd prime that does not appear is 587, according to Rowland. [_Jonathan Sondow_, Aug 14 2008]
Removing duplicates from this sequence yields A221869. The duplicates are A225487. - _Jonathan Sondow_, May 03 2013
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..5000
Jean-Paul Delahaye, Déconcertantes conjectures, Pour la science, 5 (2008), 92-97. [broken link]

Jeffrey Shallit, Rutgers Graduate Student Finds New Prime-Generating Formula, Recursivity blog.
V. Shevelev, Generalizations of the Rowland theorem, arXiv 2009
formula: Denote by Lpf(n) the least prime factor of n. Then a(n) = Lpf(6-n+sum{i=1,...,n-1}a(i)). [_Vladimir Shevelev_, Mar 03 2010]
maple: for k from 2 to n do
mathematica: f[1] = 7; f[n_] := f[n] = f[n - 1] + GCD[n, f[n - 1]]; DeleteCases[Differences[Table[f[n], {n, 10^6}]], 1] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Nov 17 2011 *)
program: ub=1000; n=3; a=9; while(n<ub, m=a\n; d=factor((m-1)*n-1)[1,1]; print1(d,", "); n=n+((d-1)\(m-1)); a=m*n; ); \\ _Daniel Constantin Mayer_, Aug 31 2014
results.author: _Jonathan Sondow_, Jan 29 2008, Jan 30 2008
